description.text:
An OpenSCAD script that generates link chain designed to print without support or post assembly.  
Update! New name, cleaned up script. Tossed out all old scad and stls.  
Update 2, May 2013. Reworked the script to generate clean link geometry. TODO (low prio): Make the code as clean as the geometry...  
Chain links are 22 x 12(15) mm with a 3.5 mm diameter cross-section. (Straight chain is 12 mm wide, others 15 mm) These dimensions are easily modified in the scad file or through customizer, but make sure to check that the links do not intersect!
Your printer needs good bed adhesion, OK overhangs and bridges. If you do succeed, just lift the chain from the bed and you are ready to go!

comments.text: Added a place to put a crew to hold on both ends. Needed as a stop for a platform slide. I will post picture installed once built.Thanks for the chain!
comments.author: CptHilts

comments.text: Printed on a Taz 6 and made sure to keep the print speed SLOW and it came out great! Thanks for the design and the instructions.
comments.author: jamesXwilcox

comments.text: For people with Da Vinci 1.0 or any other printer that doesn't have good bed adhesion make sure to put a raft on it. I also set the layer height to 2.0mm and put speed to slow. I also have 90%-Solid. Those are the settings that work the best with mine.
comments.author: rbmagic1

comments.text: Can i put stuff on the chain after it has been 3d printed?

comments.text: It is not designed for any particular printer. Your problem description is very vague so it is difficult to help. Read the instructions for this thing, and print slowly to let the plastic cool off between layers. Good luck!

comments.text: Sorry for not replying earlier. I have never tried printing hollow chains. Go for it and tell us how it went!

comments.text: Yes, that's the idea.
comments.author: inavarro

comments.text: New version again, as the last attempt had duplicated vertices due to a missing union() call. The mesh looked good, but slicing failed miserably. However, it should now be fixed in the scad, 5 and 10 link stl's.
comments.author: Sal

comments.text: A lot of the links slice/print with a bit of a hole/cut in the link. Examining the STL, it looks like the links are not entirely manifold since they have an internal wall which trips up the slicer. Any idea how to fix this? No amount of slicing tweaks seem to be able to fix it since its an STL issue. Otherwise, very cool thing!
comments.author: adielfernandez

comments.text: Ok, scad and the 5 and 10 link straight chains updated. Please try again!
comments.author: adielfernandez

comments.text: Haven't had issues with that myself (using slic3r). I will see if I can change the script to make the output cleaner.
comments.author: adielfernandez

comments.text: After too many failed prints due to knocked over links I gave in and told slicer to add a 2mm brim to the bottom layer. That turned the whole affair into (only) an overhang and bridges problem which we all know is handled by a liberal amount of cool air and slow speed. Success at last!
comments.author: Sal

If printing a complete chain fails, you might try printing separate open links lying flat on the bed. (almost like these http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67445)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... But of course not as cool as having a solid chain...

Well, I started by doing all the math for the model and found out that describing a spiral parametric chain is not the easiest exercise in the world. So I ended up tweaking the 60
Ã‚Â° angle and the spacing instead of calculating it and reached a quick solution. It only took 28' to compile (that's minutes) =-O

title: Chess Set - All in one ( ECO )

description.text:
Hello, I am a third year student at Hadassa College In Jerusalem in the industrial design department. My project refers to the problems we all have to compete when we use the 3D printing machine. Many times we started a print at the machine and it dosn't work so well so we need to start again, but what are we doing with the Piece of plastic that go wrong? most of the time we trow it away.  
My project deal with this problem, why we can't design somthing and treat to the design process in a different way? for example, when you design a chess king tool ( the most tallest chess tool) at solidwork or any other software we can built it in a different way - we can design ALL IN ONE so in any level of the printing time if the printed stop from any reason or we stop it we get another tool from the set, pawn - rook - knight - bishop - queen -king. In this way we can use the problems of the machine in an ECO friendly way.  
I made a 3D set of chess tool ALL IN ONE - You can Download the file and if the printed stop from any reason you got another tool from the set or you can stop the printing yourself and get any tool you want, one file 6 different tools.  
If you have any other Ideas for me to continue with the project i will be happy to accept them, thanks   
ido
I built it in solidworks in 6 level first i built the pawn and after that the rook, knight, bishop, queen and the king at the end

comments.text: i do like the idea but i would like if it were compatible with CADs because when i load it in a CAD all of the holes (holes in the dot in the knight and pawn) disappear. i say this because id like to make each piece have a concentric top face.

comments.text: That's the main idea of this project, you don't need all of them -  one file and six soldier in it. start the print and stop it when you get to the soldier you need

author: CHANDAN2302

description.text: Chain tracks for your various project

These can be used for anything from a drive system to a tank tread(thats what I'm using it for). The track can be adjusted for thickness depending on what you want to use it for, each section adds 10mm to the thickness and the endplate add another 5mm. There are also two types of drive gears with 5mm shafts, with 7 and 8 sided varieties.

comments.author: Smolder

comments.text:
Sure, if you notice there are three types of joints, one with the notch extending in one direction and the other has the notch extending on both sides and the last one doesnt have a notch at all. If we denote the joint with no notch | and the single sided notch -| and the one with the double notch is -|-, a set for a track would look like this
-|,-|,-|-
|-,|-,|-,|

description.text: This is a giant crayfish I modeled up to use in AD&D's Temple of Elemental Evil. I made it in Blender using the Articulated Crayfish here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243981) and positioning its limbs into the pose I wanted. Then I added the 50mm round base from here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53158) so it would be the right scale. The only changes I made to the crayfish besides rotating and moving its parts around was slightly fattening and shortening the tail sections. This made it fit a little better on the base while allowing me to increase its size a bit.

comments.text: I ended up here because I too am slowly 3D printing all the Monsters from Temple of Elemental Evil. Thank you for doing the hard part for me!

I am used to playing games with colored marbles representing people and such, 3D printing has changed the game for me.

comments.author: Nathanz

comments.text:
How did I miss seeing this earlier! Very cool derivative!
There's always a lot of confusion with the names, mostly because common regional names don't properly match the species or family the animal belongs to.
True crayfish: freshwater, claws
True lobster: marine, claws
Rock lobster / spiny lobster: marine, no claws, large thick antennae
Slipper lobster: marine, no claws, modified plate-like antennae
I used photos of the common yabby (Cherax destructor) and Murray crayfish (Euastacus armatus) for reference while modelling it.
comments.author: 4MULE8

comments.text:
when they have Claws they are called lobsters or Hummer.
clawless ones are called crayfish or spiny lobster.
comments.author: yzorg

comments.text: First I will say what a cool thing to model. ="thingiverse-492114f6915a69aa3dd005aa4233ef51:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/thingiverse-492114f6915a69aa3dd005aa4233ef51/yzorg I'm not sure where you are located because here in South Texas and Louisiana we boil crawfish in spices, corn on the cob, potatoes to eat them and they have claws just like his model. You probably think that's gross, but don't knock it until you try it. I'm not trying to be pompous with my post. I just wanted you to know the difference between crawfish, lobster and crayfish. =) ="osarusan:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/osarusan/Osarusan "Crayfish" have larger claws and are mostly used as bait when fishing. But more on topic I appreciate your work with this model. It will definitely be printed. =) p

description.text: CNC cut 15mm thick plywood chair with no need of glue or fixation bolts, just clipping the parts by pressure fitting. Manufactured at the Fab Lab Barcelona

Depending on the tolerance of the wood thickness you use, may the drawing shall be re-scaled. The slots are dimensioned nominally respect the expected wood thickness =15mm. You may do some previous test with an small board, then scale the DXF by 1 percent either increasing or decreasing till the fitting is the appropiate

Unieke samenwerking in NijverValley. Nijverdal 29-03-2014
Overeenkomst
Volgende week dinsdag tekenen Nijverdal ten Kate (leverancier van hoogwaardige gewapende thermoplasten) en Hegemann Betonbouw (bouwonderneming die gebruik maakt van speciale gewapende betonconstructies) een samenwerkingsovereenkomst om in de toekomst intensiever met elkaar te werken.
Beide bedrijven vullen elkaar aardig aan op het gebied van lichtgewicht constructies.
Nijverdal Ten Kate met gewapende thermoplastische composiet materialen die veelvuldig gebruikt worden in de luchtvaart industrie en de laatste jaren steeds meer in de automotive industrie. Deze materialen lijken nu uitermate geschikt voor extreem sterke en lichtgewicht brugdelen.
Hegemann Betonbouw heeft veel ervaring met gecompliceerde hoog belaste betonnen bruggen.
Ravijn-Fly-Over
Als pilot project wordt de nieuw te maken Ravijn-Fly-Over genoemd, een fiets-voetbrug over de nieuwe N35 en de spoorlijn in het Ravijn. Deze brug maakt deel uit van de Fietssnelweg F35 die loopt van Enschede, Hengelo, Almelo en Wierden naar het bezoekerscentrum boven op de berg in Nijverdal.
Delen van deze F35 zijn al zichtbaar bij het Nijverdalse station. Ook verbind deze Ravijn-Fly-Over het bezoekerscentrum op de Sallandse berg met het Avonturenpark en het Landalpark in Hellendoorn. Lange afstand wandelaars (gebruikers van het Pieterpad) kunnen ook van deze brug, met een adembenemend uitzicht, gebruik maken.
Unieke constructie
De fiets-voetbrug krijgt een lengte van 150 meter en bestaat uit 7 dragende pylonen waarvan de langste 18 meter boven het Ravijn uitsteekt. Op deze pylonen komen 6 zelfdragende brugdelen die elk een lengte hebben van 20 meter. De brugdelen uit versterkt thermoplast zijn 6 meter breed (4 meter voor de Fietssnelweg F35 en 1,5 meter voor het voetpad). Daar waar de brugdelen op de betonnen pylonen liggen ontstaat een rond uitzichtpunt van 12 meter met overkapping om te genieten van het prachtige uitzicht. Ook kan hier een bank geplaatst worden. De brugdelen hebben kabelkanalen voor verlichting en regenwaterafvoer onder het voetgangers deel.
Unieke samenwerking
Niet alleen deze bedrijven uit Nijverdal zijn betrokken, ook de Gemeente Hellendoorn, de Provincie Overijssel , de Regio Twente en de Fietsersbond spelen een belangrijke rol.
(zie ook http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1836785 )
A very basic "thumbscrew" to go on the head of a M3 machine screw.  10mm diameter x 5mm high.

Basically you just print a bunch of these, put a flat edge on the heads of some M3 machine screws, and push the screw heads in nice and hard with a screwdriver (a hole in a block of wood helps).
I use these with nylon M3 screws, but if you used a grinder to put a flat edge on the head of a metal machine screw it should also work.

remixed_from.author: ajayre
remixed_from.title: RepRapPro Mendel Cooling Fan Bracket III

description.text: Made a fan bracket for 70mm fans instead of the included 40mm.

A small piece used to mount a 4cm fan (3.2cmm across from center of mounting holes) Used to keep prints cool as they are in progress and to keep the fan from colliding with the vertical bars and print in progress. The fan I use is a 12V small fan that came with my Makergear hotend kit.

Print the piece. If you're printing with a Rostock, make sure that it doesn't warp (Because that's what this piece will be used for ;3) and then drill out the mounting hole if necessary. See pictures attached for where to mount fan. The fan wires are connected to D9 on RAMPS. If you want to be able to control the fan directly from Pronterface, use M106 S(0-255) to activate with power S (255 is full power) and M107 to turn it off. You can also enable cooling in Slic3r's Filament Settings>Cooling.

Based on the research of Robert Full, this tiny sheet of plastic has even tinier hairs. Not tested yet, but based on proven research. A gecko's foot uses microscopic hairs to stick to surfaces by creating a kind of a super friction. This object does the same thing, only on a smaller scale. This sheet of plastic has 224 tiny spires, and is only a few square millimeters.

Use a Replicator for this. For more friction, it is best to scale it down by .5 and make the layer height .01. THis is just for better sticking though. Will be able to print and test anywhere in between 4 and 6 weeks. I promise I will test it, but until then, try printing it yourself.

comments.text: Unfortunately you wont be able to print this with a replicator or any "cheap" printer that I know of. The nozzle diameter of most of the 3D printers whose results you see uploaded to this site are more than 0.3mm. So the prints are made up of 0.3mm wide blobs that are positioned with 0.1mm accuracy. The gecko hairs in your model are far to fine to be printed. According to wiki they need to be 0.2 micrometers which is 0.0002mm
comments.author: Jinja

comments.text: It won't be as small or strong as a gecko's foot, but smaller than previous attempts.
comments.author: Jinja

comments.text: Way ahead of you. I scaled it up slightly, so that the replicator can handle it, but it is still only about 1.5 square millimeters, and has 256 spires.
comments.author: Jinja

comments.text: I'm pretty sure there isn't a printer DIY or commercial that can print this. Just FYI.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: Yes, but if we greatly embiggen it and print, this is a great model to show how the concept works.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: Perhaps an STL printer can. They can get .01mm layer height.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: don't you mean an SLA printer? Either way this print wont work, but good idea anyway
comments.author: grabercars

comments.text: The Ultimaker can easily do .01mm layer height. It isn't the layer height that is the problem but the x-y size of the "hairs" Scaled way up it would be printable but might not work very like the hairs on a gecko's foot because they would then be too large to stick in the same fashion.
comments.author: grabercars

title: Top Mounted Spool Holder for Prusa Mendel and Prusa i2

description.text:
Print two of the "spool holder". The clips are fitted for M8 rods. There are holes for optional screw clamping the printed piece to the frame using M3x30mm screws/nuts.  
In the picture a nut-knob is visible. It is from another piece that I printed for my Prusa i3. It is also included here.

Print two of the "spool holder". The clips are fitted for M8 rods. There are holes for optional screw clamping the printed piece to the frame using M3x30mm screws/nuts.  
In the picture a nut-knob is visible. It is from another piece that I printed for my Prusa i3. It is also included here.
